lead_paragraph: Health authorities said reported cases of microcephaly — a condition in which newborns have abnormally small heads — had climbed to 4,180 since October. Brazil typically has 150 cases annually.
snippet: Health authorities said reported cases of microcephaly — a condition in which newborns have abnormally small heads — had climbed to 4,180 since October. Brazil typically has 150 cases annually.

headline.main: Reports of Zika-Linked Birth Defect Rise in Brazil
headline.print_headline: Reports of Zika-Linked Birth Defect Rise in Brazil

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

abstract: Brazilian health officials announce Zika virus is typically not life-threatening, but warns country's outdated testing methods cannot prove or disprove virus's link to surge in cases of microcephaly; Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, which has advised pregnant women to avoid traveling to affected regions, says evidence suggests connection and recommends further research.
